page.title: 09Ecology : Nature Reserve
page.content: ECOLOGY:Nature Reserve:How it began In 1981,an unemployed,unskilled labourer,Barry Jackson,spent many hours rod fishing from the revetment of Royal Seaforth Dock.He began to notice the variety of plants,insects and birds that were "adopting" the site.With expert advice,Jackson built up a dossier of all the species and contacted his local Job Centre.The Manpower Services Commission with the assistance of Merseyside Improvement Ltd.,gave Jackson Â£100,000 and 10 men to create a nature reserve. The two pools were cleared of rubbish, rusting metal and oil.Large mounds of rubbish were broken down to form smaller hummocks.In 1982 Jackson received two awards from the Conservation Foundation and in 1985 the reserve received official status with Lancs Trust for Nat.Conservation.
